data.title: Object
data.meta_description: This page covers the part of the modding tool that allows you to mod objects. Objects are things like furniture, crops, doors, obstacles, traps and so on. Some may be constructed trough blueprints. The size of this object, in tiles. A chair is 1 by 1, A bed is 2 by 2, for reference. Enabling...
data.text:
This page covers the part of the modding tool that allows you to mod objects. Objects are things like furniture, crops, doors, obstacles, traps and so on. Some may be constructed trough blueprints.

General[]

Property Description Object Name The name of the object as it appears in-game ID The ID of this object. Lowercase is recommended. Don't use spaces.

Parkour data[]

Property Description Can parkour Whether or not a character can parkour over this object. If enabled, the properties below will be visible Icon This is the icon that shows when you are standing close to the object and select the parkour option. Parkour text The text that will appear in-game when you hover the cursor over the object (and you are close enough to perform parkour) Animation call ID Probably a reference to the animation for parkour. Speed modifier Changes the speed at which you parkour over this object. 0.5 means your speed halves when you parkour over this object.

Capacity/search[]

Property Description Capacity size Indicates how much can be stored inside this object. For reference, the big metal cabinet can store 120 Icon This is the icon that will be shown for the search option (when holding E to get the pop-up menu for example). Dragging another icon (from assets) on this icon will change it. Search text This is the text that will show for the search option in-game

Durability/armor[]

Property Description Max durability The amount of damage it can take before being destroyed. The big metal cabinet uses 1000, for reference. Armor type Click on the selected armor type to change it. This will influence the armor points below Armor points The armor points associated with the selected armor type. These values can only be changed by changing the armor type

Size[]

The size of this object, in tiles. A chair is 1 by 1, A bed is 2 by 2, for reference.

Set interaction[]

Property Description Interaction object Click on 'Add new action' to add an action to the list. Click on the name of one of the actions to change it. Press Remove to remove the action from the list. The actions are defined in Inventory action data. Default interaction The default action that will be performed on the object when pressing E. Holding E will show a pop-up menu with the default option selected.

Has tool function[]

Enabling this will allow the object to act as a tool when standing close. Enter a number in one of the input fields next to the tool functions (qualities) to set the level of tool quality this object provides.

Destruction data[]

Property Description Wreckage ID The ID of a wreckage object that will appear when this object is destroyed Demolishing GFX A special effect that will appear when this object is demolished Hit Sound The sound that will play when this object is hit Destruction sound The sound that will play when this object is destroyed

Disassemble data[]

Property Description Icon The icon that will show when hovering over an object and disassemble is the default action. If it's not the default action, it will appear in the pop-up menu when holding E on the object. You can change it by dragging an image from the assets onto the icon Disassemble text The text that will appear for the disassemble action in-game Result item A list of items that will appear when the disassemble action is complete. You can set a minimum and a maximum per item. The actual amount of items that will appear in-game will be a random amount between the minimum and the maximum. Required skill level A list of skills required to perform the disassemble action on this object. Maybe a higher skill level will improve the amount of resulting items, capping it at the max level configured? Required tool level A list of tool quality levels required to perform the disassemble action on this object. Maybe a higher tool quality level will improve the amount of resulting items, capping it at the max level configured? The tool qualities are defined in tool types. Time The amount of minutes it takes to disassemble this object

Destruction remain items[]

Property Description Destruction Remaining data Allows you to specify what items and how much of it will appear when the object is destroyed. The actual amount of items that will appear in-game is somewhere between the provided min and max amount. Remain item The ID of an item that will remain after the object is destroyed. You can add multiple Min The minimum amount of this item that will appear after this object is destroyed. Max The maximum amount of items that will appear after this object is destroyed.

Set resource storage[]

Configuring a resource storage for an object will create a meter on the object in-game. This opens up a lot of possibilities. It can be as simple as a water dispenser where you only take water out, or it can be something more complicated, like putting gasoline in and then let it drain to create electric power. You can define multiple resource types.

Property Description Charging type ID The ID of a charging type. Default storage The amount of this resource it spawns with Max storage The maximum amount of this resource that can be stored in this object Delta per hour The amount of this resource that will increase or decrease per hour. A positive number will increase the amount of resource stored and a negative amount will drain this resource per hour. Can import manually Whether or not you can manually input this resource type. If disabled, you can give the player the option of importing the resource trough the 'Set interaction' options (see above) Can export manually Whether or not you can manually export this resource type. If disabled, you can give the player the option of exporting the resource trough the 'Set interaction' options (see above)

Set activating effect[]

This allows you to set a variety of effects when interacting with this object. For example:

Turn it off when it runs out of resources

Deal damage/give health when it is destroyed

Turn it into something else, like when you would unfold a folded object into an unfolded object.

The image below shows an effect that is triggered manually by the player, or automatically when it runs out of gas. The effect is configured in the 'portable_gas_generator_on' and will transform itself into the 'portable_gas_generator' when triggered.

Property Description Call ID The ID of the function that is called in this effect. It's filled automatically when pressing 'Add new activating' and doesn't need to be canged Transform automatic The ID of the object it will transform into when this effect triggers Can activate manually Whether or not the player can activate this effect manually before it triggers automatically Activating Icon The icon that will appear in the menu when holding the E key in-game. You can change it by dragging an image from the assets onto the icon Activating text The text that will appear in the menu when holding the E key in-game. Trigger charging type ID The ID of a charging type that will be used to trigger the effect. Trigger type The type of trigger for this effect. The options are 'Lack_of_charging_type', 'Full_of_charging_type' and 'None'. Object effect The effect of this object that will occur after the trigger has occurred Sound effect The sound effect that will play when this effect is triggered Add new activating Adds a new activating option to this object. When adding a new effect, the options are 'Transform', 'Transform automatic', 'Transform with function', 'Disassemble' and 'Destruction'

Set rendering[]

Property Description Rendering type Options are 'Baseground' (for crops and traps), 'General' (for most objects, like furniture and doors) and 'End' (not sure what this is for) is passable Whether or not you pass trough this object. Useful for 'Baseground' objects since you walk over them. Enabling this will negate the effect of set collider. pass light Whether or not light passes trough this object pass bullets Whether or not bullets pass trough this object has light If enabled, this object will light up the area Light intensity How intense the light is. The solar lamp post has an intensity of 2, for reference Light range The range of the light in pixels. The solar lamp post has a range of 600, for reference Light color The color of the light that is emitted.

Set sprite[]

Property Description Durability ratio This basically lets you set damage 'levels' for your object. This is used to visualize damage. For every level you configure here you will be able to select a sprite of what your object will look like with that amount of health left. In the example above, there are three levels. 100%, 80% and 40%. Notice how these numbers also appear above the sprites. Adding more then one durability ratio is not required but it adds to the immersion. Capacity ratio Allows you to set levels of capacity for this object. This is used to visualize how much stuff is inside this object. For every level you configure, you will be able to select a sprite of what your object will look like with that amount of stuff in it, as a percentage of it's capacity. In the example above it will show one sprite when it is 60-100% full and a different sprite when it is 2-60% full. It is not required to add more then one capacity level. North/south/west/east sprite You are able to select a sprite for each of the directions your object may face. A round object like a barrel may use one sprite for each of the directions but a chair may have one for each direction. Copy from Helps you to copy the settings from another direction to this direction. This is used for convenience. Base/durability/capacity sprites The base sprite is always present. For the base and each of the durability/capacity ratio's you can select a sprite by dragging a sprite from the assets onto the sprite name Has animation See below

Has animation

Property Description Has animation If enabled, allows you to configure a number of frames that will be cycled trough to create an animation. Sprite A preview and the name of a sprite for this frame. Drag a sprite from the assets to the sprite name to change it. The base sprite will always be visible, and each frame sprite will be drawn on top of it so be sure your sprites have transparent backgrounds. Time The amount of seconds this sprite will be visible before changing to the next sprite. This helps to time the animation in-game. Since animation is typically 24 frames a second, 0,05 will work most of the time. Has light Whether or not this frame should emit light when it is visible. By enabling it for some but not for other frames, you could create a flicker effect Light color Lets you pick the color of the light Intensity The intensity of the light. For reference, the solar lamp pole has 2 Range The range of the light. For reference, the solar lamp pole has 600

Set collider[]

This lets you set the area on which characters will collide with this object (if passable is checked off under set rendering). It will always be as big as the size. The size is measured in tiles. In the example below, the size of the object is 3 by 1, so in the horizontal orientation it is 3 tiles wide and 1 tile high. In the vertical orientation it is 3 tiles high and 1 tile wide.

Set local position[]

This is used for instances where the player can position themselves on the object, like a bed.
